body: On the nature of light and refraction.
Your thoughts on refraction are compelling.
I am honored by your invitation to Stockholm.
The pendulum experiments proceed well.
On the weight of air and the void.
On the problem of points and probability.
Your solution is elegant. I propose another approach.
The air pump design shows great promise.
I have improved upon your pendulum clock.
On the logic of Port-Royal.
Please assist with the new experiments.
The microscope reveals astonishing structures.
I wish to communicate my findings to the Society.
The Royal Society welcomes your correspondence.
Observations on the comet of this year.
Publication of the Transactions proceeds.
On the method of fluxions.
Further developments on the calculus.
Your work surpasses my own. I yield the chair.
The Society is eager to see your optical work.
On the composition of white light.
I seek introduction to English natural philosophers.
You are welcome to correspond with our members.
On the nature of light: a reply to criticisms.
I maintain that light is a wave phenomenon.
On your work with the pendulum and curves.
The involute of the cycloid is itself a cycloid.
The binomial theorem and infinite series.
I have my own methods for these calculations.
My calculus notation may prove useful.
Your notation is clear and promising.
On planetary motion and the inverse square law.
I had considered these problems years ago.
I require your astronomical observations.
The comet observations are enclosed.
What curve would a planet describe?
An ellipse. I calculated it some time ago.
You must publish this. I will fund the printing.
The Principia manuscript is nearly complete.
The Principia is published. The world is changed.
My Treatise on Light is published at last.
I am recovering from a period of great distress.
On the brachistochrone problem.
The challenge is issued to the mathematicians of Europe.
I solved the brachistochrone in an evening.
Newton's priority claims grow louder.
I insist on the publication of your catalogue.
The Opticks is published with the fluxions appendix.
The Royal Society's committee is not impartial.
On the argument from design and celestial mechanics.
